section.title: Fronting
section.sectiontitle: We can start a sentence with a complement (object, verb, adjective or adverb) to emphasise the complement.
section.text1: The film was long but it wasn't interesting!
section.sectiontitle2: We can use what or another question word to begin the sentence.
section.text3: It's impossible to say what she wants.
section.text4: I've no idea why you're telling me this!
section.text4a: Why you're telling me this I've no idea!

section.title: Fronting
section.sectiontitle: We can front verbs and adjectives with as and though.
section.text1: I was hungry, but I didn't eat until everyone had finished.
section.text1a: Hungry though I was, I didn't eat until everyone had finished.
section.text2: He tried to find a job, but he couldn't.
section.text2a: Try as he did, he couldn't find a job.
section.sectiontitle2: There are many common 'fronting phrases' which are used for emphasis: the trouble is ..., the fact remains that ..., the question is ...
section.text3a: The question is, do we want to sell the company?
section.text4a: The trouble is, he's never really understood the business.

section.title: Fronting
section.sectiontitle: We can use fronting to link what we are saying to information that was given earlier. This sounds quite formal.
section.text1a: David mentioned changing the laws. But that idea we've already tried.
section.text2a: I know you've seen our old paintings, but these you probably haven't seen.
